docs.snippet: Miller's Barley Beer    Having covered the market with regular, light, dry, draft and nonalcoholic beers, it looks as if the Miller Brewing Company is now taking on the fancier beers, imports and beers made by micro-breweries. The latest entries i...
docs.lead_paragraph: Miller's Barley Beer Having covered the market with regular, light, dry, draft and nonalcoholic beers, it looks as if the Miller Brewing Company is now taking on the fancier beers, imports and beers made by micro-breweries. The latest entries in the Miller stable are draft, regular and light versions of Miller Reserve 100 percent barley.

docs.snippet: It's not just true of New York, Los Angeles or Miami. Every naked city has a million squalid stories hatching under its smog. ''Junk Food,'' Masashi Yamamoto's collage of urban vignettes unfolding simultaneously over a single day insists that even...
docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews Junk Food, movie by Masashi Yamamoto; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: It's not just true of New York, Los Angeles or Miami. Every naked city has a million squalid stories hatching under its smog. ''Junk Food,'' Masashi Yamamoto's collage of urban vignettes unfolding simultaneously over a single day insists that even nice, orderly Tokyo has a fetidly seamy lowlife. This icy little movie, which opens today at the Film Forum, has the exploitative feel of a can-you-top-this sampler of urban maladies, all viewed with an unnerving detachment. Some of its scenes are little more than snapshots of dramas whose backgrounds and details remain unexplained. Others are fuller portraits of people in serious trouble who lash out with a lethal fury that seems totally out of proportion to what sets them off.

headline.main: More on the Menu Than Merely Weight

docs.snippet: As concern about breast cancer continues to rise, mammography has become a booming business in this country. But some of the business has been too good, studies have shown, leading to an overabundance of clinics, high prices and poor x-rays.   Las...
docs.lead_paragraph: As concern about breast cancer continues to rise, mammography has become a booming business in this country. But some of the business has been too good, studies have shown, leading to an overabundance of clinics, high prices and poor x-rays. Last week the Food and Drug Administration, under pressure from Senator Barbara Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, announced stricter standards on breast x-rays. The new rules require that the country's 12,000 clinics pass inspection and be accredited, use up-to-date equipment and trained technicians, keep complete records and undergo annual audits. The rules take effect Oct. 1, 1994, but clinics are expected to start upgrading now.

headline.main: NOV. 28-DEC. 4: New Rules on Breast X-Rays; F.D.A. Raises Standard For Mammography Clinics

docs.snippet: To-Stay Food, to Go    Carmine's, a family-style Italian restaurant on upper Broadway, has just opened a takeout shop. Now, instead of waiting for hours for a table and taking home the leftovers, customers can skip the restaurant and buy the food ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To-Stay Food, to Go Carmine's, a family-style Italian restaurant on upper Broadway, has just opened a takeout shop. Now, instead of waiting for hours for a table and taking home the leftovers, customers can skip the restaurant and buy the food to go.

docs.snippet: Tomatoes for All Seasons    For the family of Nancy Distefano, a 30-year-old former fabric designer from Flushing, Queens, as for many Italian-American families, summer meant putting up plum tomatoes by to use all year. Now, capitalizing on a fami...
docs.lead_paragraph: Tomatoes for All Seasons For the family of Nancy Distefano, a 30-year-old former fabric designer from Flushing, Queens, as for many Italian-American families, summer meant putting up plum tomatoes by to use all year. Now, capitalizing on a family tradition, she packages and sells tomato sauces commercially.

docs.snippet: 'Food'  White Columns  154 Christopher Street  West Village  Through March 1      In austere black and white -- photographs, typed statements and, best of all, four recently discovered videotapes by the sculptor Gordon Matta-Clark -- this exhibiti...
docs.abstract: Roberta Smith reviews exhibit at White Columns gallery documenting short life of SoHo restaurant named Food, which opened in fall of 1971; Food was run by and for artists, and was partly conceived as form of performance art (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: 'Food' White Columns 154 Christopher Street West Village Through March 1 In austere black and white -- photographs, typed statements and, best of all, four recently discovered videotapes by the sculptor Gordon Matta-Clark -- this exhibition documents the short, intense, wonderfully casual life of the SoHo restaurant Food. Run by and for artists, and partly conceived as a form of performance art, Food opened on the northwest corner of Wooster and Prince Streets in the fall of 1971, when ''Soho'' still referred to part of central London.

docs.snippet: Seeking to resolve one of the most difficult scientific and legal conflicts involving the nation's food supply, a Federal Court of Appeals ruled today that the Environmental Protection Agency must remove from the market any pesticides that both ha...
docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to resolve one of the most difficult scientific and legal conflicts involving the nation's food supply, a Federal Court of Appeals ruled today that the Environmental Protection Agency must remove from the market any pesticides that both have the potential to cause cancer and leave residues in processed foods. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, ruled that such pesticides were covered by a 34-year-old provision of the Food, Drug and Cosmetics Act. The regulation prohibits even trace amounts of any potentially carcinogenic additive in juices, breads, jellies, flour or thousands of other processed foods.

headline.main: Court Expands Pesticide Ban To Cover Many Used in Food

docs.snippet: Passover Pricing    Along with setting aside shelves for boxes of matzoh and jars of gefilte fish, grocers have also been known to jack up prices for Passover. Starting last year, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs has waged a campai...
docs.lead_paragraph: Passover Pricing Along with setting aside shelves for boxes of matzoh and jars of gefilte fish, grocers have also been known to jack up prices for Passover. Starting last year, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs has waged a campaign to prevent such price gouging by wholesalers and retailers.
